response.answer_text: Someone anonymous's answer to How can I write a letter? has covered the professional letters you might want to write very well. What if you want to write a personal letter to someone that they can hold and cherish as something meaningful from you? I have saved every letter that people have written in their own hand and sent to me.  One of my friends still sends me handwritten letters. It is okay if you do not know how to write cursive, which apparently isn't being taught anymore in US schools. In the upper left corner of the writing paper, he puts the city from which he is writing (he has traveled a lot) and the date. This is a great practice for historical purposes when you look over the detritus of your life later on.  Sometimes he will include a simple line drawing that is relevant to where he's at, either physically or mentally. It's okay if you're not as talented as this guy. He doesn't think he's talented -- he is just doing what he likes to do. That's what you should do, too.  If you don't have "talent" you can always go to the craft store and find tons of fun stickers or rubber stamps to decorate your paper in a way that reflects your personality and mood. You can even find paper-making kits at craft stores and make your own stationary out of your junk mail and write your letters on that. You'll have to experiment with writing tools on the recycled paper, though, as it can be very porous and some ink will bleed like crazy. Some people like to add scents to their papers. Don't do this unless you know the person likes it. Scents make some sensitive people ill. The mail handlers might not appreciate them, either. I have cold-written my letters without drafting anything first. It keeps things fresh and real, but if you're not comfortable with that, make a draft and then copy it onto your nice paper. Whenever I screw up, I just black out the words and keep going. I don't use pencil to write letters because the graphite rubs off and fades with time.  For subject matter, I try to stick to an overview of what has happened in my life since the friend last saw me and not get into too may details if I haven't seen or written to the friend in a long time. I try to refer to a memory as a touchstone for our friendship. Thanks for your A2A. Letter writing to friends is a great habit to cultivate.

What kind of letter do you want to write? What’s the purpose, and who is your reader? Writing a letter demands the same thinking process as everything else you write for your work. Define your goal, then closely consider the person or group you want to communicate with. Every letter—like every e-mail or speech or resume or blog or performance review—is an “ask.” Think: What result do I want? And why should the reader give that to me? That requires you to take the other person’s viewpoint and see the request through their eyes. If it’s someone you know, you already own a lot of information about what motivates them, their priorities, values and hot buttons. Draw on your intuition, which is based on experience. If you’re writing to a stranger, make an educated guess based on their position and role. A CFO, for example, cares about different things than the head of IT or HR or PR does. Once you define goal and audience, it’s easy to figure out your best content to win the “ask.” Make a list, shuffle it into a logical order. Then write a draft, usually starting with the reason you’re writing, followed by the most important point that connects what you want with your audience. Proceed to your other points and say just enough to answer the question: Why should the reader agree? Would I? Then review your content—too much? Too little? Anything missing? And edit your language so it is simple and clear. End politely and circle back to repeat what you want, or the next step. As far as good formatting goes, there’s a ton of examples online that show you how to arrange a formal letter. Important to remember: These days, a letter does not necessarily mean a message delivered by the post office. When you write an e-mail that matters to you a lot, and/or it’s critical that you be perceived as capable and professional, think of it as a letter. For example, an e-mail introducing your resume for a job application, or presenting a proposal, is a letter! A response to a customer compaint is a letter! So is a networking message that asks for a favor of any kind, These messages and many more demand your best thinking and writing skills. A careless cover letter will probably cut you out of the running. A sloppy inconsiderate e-mail loses you a customer—or maybe hundreds of them—or an important opportunity. I receive a number of “how do I write” requests via Quora, and am amazed at how many of them say “how do I write a letter to ask…” Obviously, contrary to popular assumption, the digital revolution has not killed letters. They adapt and survive. And it's interesting that a physical letter-writing revival may be under way because unlike digital media, we can control distribution so much better. It’s a million times more likely to find your e-mail or tweet or social media message amusing or angering people all over the world. Letters are private, unless you have really bad luck with the person youre writing to. And of course a letter is a much more personal way to communicate. Smart businesspeople use letters to promote relationships and be remembered.

Addison Hughes 123 ABC Street Greencastle, IN 99999 3/1/2018 Quora Reader WWW Quora Blvd Quora, USA 17623 Dear Quora Reader, So you want to write a formal letter? Good for you! This Guide will help you to construct a logical, well-built letter. There are six main parts to the letter. After I have finished the letter, I will put a template for reference at the bottom. The first main part of the letter is a block of text stating your name, address, and the date the letter was sent. This is important especially if you are expecting a response sooner rather than later! The second part is a similar block of text naming the person you are sending the letter to and their address. While not necessary, this part makes it all look more professional, so I would urge you to do that. The third part is the salutation, a formal greeting to your reader. In a standard letter, it is the “Dear ______” section. The fourth part is the body. This is the part that contains most of the information contained in the letter. In this sample letter, the last three paragraphs of text from “so” until now is the body. Another optional part is the last paragraph. In this paragraph, you will simply end your letter on a good note, which can really help to make a good impression. This is the last part of the letter before the sign off, where you just leave a short kind note, followed by a reiteration of your name. Hopefully with this sample and the template at the bottom of this answer, you will be well on your way to writing a good letter! Happy writing! Kindly, Addison Hughes  TEMPLATE: Your Name Your Address Your Address The Date Recipient’s Name Recipient’s Address Recipient’s Address Salutation, Body Paragraph—————————————————————————————→ Body Paragraph—————————————————————————————→ Body Paragraph—————————————————————————————→ Final, Friendly Paragraph————————————————————————→ Sign Off, Your Name

Depending on the type of letter you are writing these are the steps to follow. INFORMAL LETTER The address It should be at the top right corner of the paper. It can be blocked of indented. It consists of the writer's name, postal code and place of writing. Example; Esther Bediako, Ideal College International, Pmb 16 community one, Tema- Ghana. Or Esther Bediako, Ideal College International, Pmb 16 community one, Tema- Ghana. In actual sense the indented one should be like this \. Date It is located right under the address. Note: it is not part of the date. Esther Bediako, Ideal College International, Pmb 16 community one, Tema- Ghana. 20th- February- 2018. Salutation It is written after the date at the left hand side of the paper and neatly punctuated. Examples; Hey Jeff, Hi Skido, Hello Anibal, etc. The introduction It should send an information of what you are putting across. The body It contains the message which you want to send your pal, neatly written in paragraphs. It can contain informal language, slangs and contracted form of word. The conclusion It raps up the message in the letter. The subscription It comes in the forms; Your friend, Yours ever and many others. Note: this is a letter to a pen pal and so you must stick to it rules. FORMAL LETTER The writer's address It consist of the name of the writer,postal code, position and place of writing. It can either be blocked or indented. It is written at the top write corner of the sheet. The date It is located under the writer's address at the right corner. The recipient address It is located at the left corner of the paper just after the date. It can be in a block in the block or indented form. It contains the name and position of the recipient, postal code and place of writing. Salutation It is written under the recipient address. It comes in the form Dear Sir/ Madam and it ends with a comma. “,”. The heading / title It is the summary of thein message in the body of the letter. It is written in capital letters and neatly underlined. For instance; you've been given this question. Write a letter to your principal informing him of three problems faced by female students on campus. You need to derive a topic from the question. Like, THREE PROBLEMS FACED BY FEMALE STUDENTS ON CAMPUS.And it should neatly be underlined. The body The body of the letter should contain an introductory paragraph of the message to be shared. It is the message the writer wants to put across to the reader. It contains highly formal language devoided of slangs and contracted form of words like; “can't”, “don't”, “wouldn't”, “couldn't” and some others. Instead you use, “cannot”, “ do not”, “ would not”, “could not” and the likes. It is simple and straight forward. It is arranged in clear/ cut paragraphs. The conclusion It ends the message you are sending to the reader. And it begins like; “To end with”, “ To sum up”, “To conclude”, “ In a but shell”, and many others. The subscription It comes in the forms; “Your Student”, “ Yours Sincerely”, “ Yours Faithfully”. It is located under the body of the letter at the right hand side of the sheet and ends with a comma. The signature It is written under the the subscription. The name It is written under the signature at the right hand side of the paper. Example; Yours Sincerely, %&££^^~~~~~ Esther Bediako. Note: Your work should be neat and clarified.Your work should be neatly punctuated and informative…

Depends in what you’re writing the email for. If it’s for an exam or anything educational, follow the basic principles of letter writing: Opening statement: address the receiver and state the main purposeBody of the email: explain your purpose in three-four linesConclusion: close your email with a summary (if relevant) and thanksThis should help you get a good score for your email writing. However— If you’re writing an email at work, you can bend the principles. The most important thing to remember in writing an email (or anything) is the audience. If it’s for your colleagues/supervisors, Explain the purpose in the subject line.Convey the main point in a line or two. Don’t beat around the bush—people don’t have time for rambling.Close with your name and designation, if relevant.If it’s for customers/prospects, Stick to the same structure, but also watch out for these: If you’re answering a support ticket, reiterate the customer’s question or problem to show that you’ve understood what they said.Be specific and direct—if you don’t know the answer and need someone else to fix an issue/bug, say so. Explain that developers are looking into it.Don’t promise timelines unless you’re sure about it. But if you know it’s going to take two days, tell the customer. Don’t keep customers in the dark.General pointers on writing good emails: Use simple words as in a normal conversation. Real life emails aren’t like essay writing tests. No one cares about fancy vocabulary if they don’t understand what you say.Practice being empathic. Sympathy is letting the other person know you’re sorry for them, but empathy is experiencing the other person’s problems as your own. This will make your tone more understanding and relatable.Read books and articles about writing effective email copy.Keep improving your overall language and writing skills.Resources: Writing That Works — I’ve read this and it has some great pointers about getting to the point—especially in emails.Everybody Writes — A relatable book with advice that’s easy to understand and follow.30 Empathy Statements & Phrases that Show Customers You CareThanks for asking me to answer. Hope this helps.

Chimpanzees are quite adept at writing letters with their feet as well as their hands, though they are not always sure what to put in them. Thus, it depends who you are writing the letter to. Generally speaking, you write your name and address in the top right hand corner and the recipient’s name and address in the top left hand corner, though if you are posting the letter in an envelope, the window is normally low down so you might need to position the recipient’s details lower than your own, otherwise the postman wont be able to see it. A way round this is to fold the paper appropriately, unless of course you are using a large envelope Letters normally begin with dear Sir or dear Madam, and will consequently end with Yours faithfully, but if you specify the person’s name, you end the letter with Yours sincerely. As Johan Vanderjagt has correctly pointed out, it is easier to write a letter by using a pen or a pencil held in your dominant hand. This also applies to people who live in the UK and the USA, though if you are younger than say 6, this might be difficult as they may not yet have mastered the necessary skills. People often use computers when writing letters and they do this by hitting keys on a keyboard, or a keypad if they’re using a smart phone or tablet. Some people are quite good at using their fingers and thumbs, though I personally can only use the long finger of my left hand for some strange reason, but it’s nothing to be ashamed of.

I’m not expert in writing letters but I do write letters sometimes. There are two types of letter. Formal & informal, as Nilah Khan mentioned in previous answer. I’ll go with formal. I would begin writing with the address of myself with “From,” in beginning and after my name,address and other necessary details. I would leave a line in between and go for another line with right alignment for the receiver’s address by starting with “To,”. After that, we’ll write subject in center alignment, we’ll go with writing the letter. To make it paragraph, leave space of two lines before you begin. And begin like this. “With the respect to the above mentioned subject, I,[Your Name Here],would like to bring you attention towards [Your Request].” This would take around 2–3 times. We’ll move to next paragraph now to go and explain what you need and why you are writing this. If necessary, use more than three paragraph. Now we’ll go to last paragraph in which we’ll write that if we need/request/process our stuff in urgency, or whatever formally you could write. Now with informal, I would begin with any random greetings like. “Dear bestie, How are you? I hope you’re busy with your girlfriend and you haven’t forgetten me after you’ve settled down on Mars.” Note :- I’m not any expert but I just write random stuffs on my blogs whenever in mood, haha. So I hope that I don’t get critics. - Manal Shaikh

The answer depends on if it’s a business letter, a complaint letter, a debate letter, or one to a close friend or relative - and even within those parameters your attitude would be different toward every person you write to. In anything but letters to friends and family, you’d probably include their address and a formal or loosely formal address above the salutation. Okay. Family and friend letters don’t necessarily need those elements, but the date and a salutation that’s meaningful between the two of you: Hi Mom; Hey Dude; What’s going on, buddy? - as I say, personal, intimate, etc. Next, in the more formal letter, keep it pretty darn formal, depending on the nature of your topic. You might get a little humorous, if it’s pertinent, or miffed, angry, elated, whatever you want to convey. It can be staunchly business, straight-laced, or even light-hearted. Any kind of letter: it all depends. Too many variables to nail down. Once finished, follow similar suggestions. Sign off with your full and formal name for straight-laced business, then first names, nicknames, secret names, and so on for an totally informal sign-off. Letters and their rules are a wide, wide range of this and that. Go by how you want to present yourself to the receiver - dead serious or satirical or loving or - okay, you probably get my drift. Happy letter writing. Be happy.

Are you asking how to write the alphabet or to write to someone else? If the former, you need more assistance than I can provide at this time. As to the former, the format is rather simple: Date Salutation (Dear Mom), [use a Subject Line if this is a business or formal letter] (SUBJECT: Camp is Great!) Body: (I learned how to water ski at camp today. The nurse says the casts will be off by the time I get home. You should have seen me flying across the lake. What that tree was doing in the middle of the water is beyond me.) Complimentary closing (Sincerely,) Name and/or of the author of the letter

The primary thing to do in writing an email us to put yourself into the shoes if the intended recipients. If you were to receive the mail, would you understand it? If not, write more clearly.Is there information that the recipient already knows? If so, cut it out.Is there information that is extraneous to the main purpose of your mail? If so cut it out.Don't appear either ingratiating or rude.Spell check and grammar check your mails before sending.Don't bcc anyone.Don't cc the mail to anyone who needs it.Explain why you're sending the mail right at the beginning of the mail.Make sure that the mail is split into paragraphs.Ensure that there is, in general, only one idea per para.You are good to go.

There is no single best way to write a letter. It all depends on who you’re writing to, and in what context. A friendly letter to a family member? A letter of condolence? An application for leave? A business query? A complaint about a problem? As a general rule of thumb, get to the point from the first line itself. Avoid beating around the bush - and excess verbiage. There’s no need to be overly formal in business letters - one can be both polite and informal at the same time. Before starting on your letter, it might be a good idea to have a checklist of points you want to cover in your missive.

First you should know the body of mail can have three paragraphs. The first paragraph is the called the opening. It is contained the overall idea. It is sometimes called the thesis statement. At this point you need to be precise, brief and to the point. The opening paragraph can have three to five sentences. What ever it takes to you make sure it conveys the main frame of your reason for writing. The second paragraph is the main body of your mail letter. Here, you should explain the most important message that your letter carries and in a detail. The last paragraph is the closing. Make sure that you concluded your mail in a proper way.

Did you know you can get books with sample letters to meet pretty much any need you might encounter? Some of them are rather quaint, written and published decades if not centuries ago, but they can usually be brushed up a bit and at least they may give you a few ideas. They were very popular in earlier times and people like Samuel Richardson grew rich on them. He was the author of the rightly scandalous “Clarissa”, which told of the downfall of a decent young woman a the hands of a rake named Lovelace. (“Clarissa” is what is known as an epistolary novel, BTW.) Modern equivalents, if there are such things, are unlikely to to offer hints on seduction or worse! Alternatively, there might be some evening classes you could attend, or you could even look around for a private tutor. Practice make perfect too, you know.

I’m assuming you are referring to writing to a friend, not referring to writing business letters. When writing to a friend, write as if you are talking to the person to whom you are writing. Don’t be too formal, just be yourself. If you ARE referring to writing business letters, there are a lot of books available that will give you good advice. Just make sure that the books are not from more than about five years ago as the rules of how to write a good business letter have changed dramatically in recent times. Business letters nowadays are very short and to the point and very specific.

Writing a letter to somebody is no different from speaking to them in person, except that in a letter, you get the advantage of clearly organizing your thoughts and presenting them. Also, you are in no danger of interruption or distraction as in a conversation. Your question does not clarify the kind of letter you want to write: Personal, business, or professional. Today’s Internet age offers you a wide variety of samples for any kind of letter. Choose the format and style elements, but let the content be your own. After all, you want yourself heard, or read for that matter! Hope this helps.

The best way to write an effective letter is to learn from letters written by others. Pick up a book on letter writing from a store near you. You will learn how to write an effective letter and also get to read all the sample letters in the book given as examples! Now you go and write one yourself!

A2A Let me divide the whole activity into 3 parts. The greetings.All professional mails must begin with greetings. If it is towards a colleague or employee of equal rank, it can be moderately casual. For eg. Dear NickFor mails to seniors, writing the word “respected” is not mandatory. Just beginning with “Sir or Ma'am" is equally good.The subject and contentMake sure the subject is short and covers the crux of the mail.Make sure the content is to the point, structured, has a logical flow. Writing point wise is even better.Sign offSign off with a “thank you” or “regards" followed by your signature which can generally be set as default.Mailing is a part of communication.
